thread.title: Twitter takes on Oscars' best picture snafu - CNN.com
thread.title_full: Twitter takes on Oscars' best picture snafu - CNN.com

author: Madison Park
title: Twitter takes on Oscars' best picture snafu - CNN.com
text: — jesse Williams. (@iJesseWilliams) February 27, 2017 Maybe this wasn't an actual blunder, hypothesized some viewers. Perhaps this was just a shocking plot twist directed by M. Night Shyamalan. the oscars, directed by m night shyamalan — Bob Vulfov (@bobvulfov) February 27, 2017 The director responded to the theory. I wrote the ending of the academy awards 2017. @jimmykimmel we really got them! — M. Night Shyamalan (@MNightShyamalan) February 27, 2017 Of course, political jokes ensued. Warren Beatty and #FayeDunaway just announced Hillary Clinton has in fact won the election!!! #BestPicture #Oscars #FakeNews #FakeAwards — Cenk Uygur (@cenkuygur) February 27, 2017 You know what the problem is -- millions of Academy members voted illegally. — Seth MacFarlane (@SethMacFarlane) February 27, 2017 Guarantee there will be more investigation into the #Oscars2017 #BestPicture mixup than #Russia 's interference in our election. #Oscars — aasif mandvi (@aasif) February 27, 2017 Some smelled a perfect marketing opportunity. Get the name wrong? We offer 24hr grace periods to correct minor errors. So you won't be left in La La Land. #Oscars https://t.co/OJfTN8vOrA pic.twitter.com/NVtD9TDeB3 It wasn't such a golden opportunity for PriceWaterHouseCoopers, though. I feel sorry for anyone having Price Waterhouse Coopers preparing their taxes — Dave Itzkoff (@ditzkoff) February 27, 2017 Regardless of how it unfolded Sunday night, some tweeted how groundbreaking it was for "Moonlight" to take the top prize. Nothing that happened on the stage should overshadow the major achievement of #Moonlight winning #BestPicture at the #Oscars tonight. pic.twitter.com/4S9bv9kUkI
